title: One-minute questions
text:
After each class session, you are expected to give a brief summary of what happened in that session as well as pointing to things that either 1) were particularly meaningful to you or 2) that you found confusing.
These are called one-minute questions to indicate roughly how much time you should spend on your answer. Of course, you are welcome to spend more time. But even if you spend just one minute, your answer should be honest, articulate, and aimed at improving the class for yourself and your student colleagues.
Your answers will count toward class participation.
DO NOT write your answer while still in class.

title: About
text:
At the University of Austin, our students pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies. As part of their required course of study, students must complete a core curriculum called the Intellectual Foundations, which consists of 15 intensive courses that introduce students to the various languages of understanding and teach them to see things whole. As part of this sequence, students are challenged to confront timeless questions beginning in antiquity and culminating in the present day.
There are two quantitative reasoning courses in the Intellectual Foundation curriculum. These are:

Quantitative Reasoning I (â€œQR â€” Analysisâ€), which teaches students the mathematical modeling tools useful for modelling real-world phenomena.
Quantitative Reasoning II (â€œQR â€” Dataâ€), which teaches students to extract useful information from data using modern data science techniques.

Both QR â€” Analysis and QR â€” Data are unlike the introductory courses found at almost all other colleges and universities. We have selected topics based on their utility in modern professional work. In contrast, basic topics in the traditional curriculum reflect the historical development of mathematics rather than the needs of modern work. Modern topics widely used in the economy and scientific/technical worlds are relegated to so-called â€œadvancedâ€ courses far downstream where they are inaccessible to almost all students.
Our two QR courses dramatically streamline the pre-requisites for successful work with modern quantitative topics. Surprisingly often the â€œadvancedâ€ topics are readily accessible to students, so long as one is willing to move beyond traditional pedagogy and avoid unwarranted devotion to topics that were important historically but are no longer necessarily for understanding.

Exercise 5 Light bulbs generally have a quantity printed on them: the wattage. Similarly, light-bulb sockets often have a â€œmax wattsâ€ label advising the user of the largest wattage bulb that can work safely in the socket.

Part a

What is the dimension of a watt?



 bulb-wattage

TipAnswer





Since people donâ€™t directly perceive electrical current or voltage, it is hard to form an intuition about them. Instead, training is required to interpret properly the meanings of electrical dimensions.
An exact mathematical analogy to electrical dimensions can be made to water and flow. You turn on the shower and step in for four minutes. As you shower, at each instant you can feel the â€œintensityâ€ (flow) of the spray from the shower-head. You even have a faucet to set the flow. This flow is analogous to the power used by a light bulb.
Over the full course of your 4-minute shower, six gallons of water goes down the train. Gallons, of course, have the dimension of volume. You used those six gallons over four minutes. Consequently, the flow of water is \(\frac{6\, \text{gallons}}{4\, \text{minutes}} = 1.5\, \text{gallons per minute}\). The volume of water used in your shower session is analogous to the energy used by a light bulb: it is power multiplied by duration. ..id..

This is the bind facing governments in much of the rich world. Exercise 11 Figure 2.1 displays child mortality versus gross domestic product (GDP) on a country-by-country basis. Child mortality is operationalized as the number of children who die between birth and their fifth birthday. It is a â€œrateâ€ because the number given is a ratio of the number of deaths in this group to the total number of children in this group, but is given in units of â€œdeaths per 1000 children.â€ That is, the ratio is dimensionless with dimension C C-1 = [1], (Strictly speaking, the rate should be called â€œUnder-five mortality.â€)
GDP is often presented as the value of goods and services produced by a country in one year. The quantity shown here is also a rate, described in the label of the graph as â€œGDP per capita.â€ The dimension of the GDP is W T-1 C-1. The operationalization of GDP is defined in a way that makes it relatively easy to measure from government and commercial records. All goods and services for which money is exchanged are included. No goods and services for which money is not exchanged are included. Thus, GDP ignores the value provided by, for instance, home child care and home meal preparation. A country which switched from home-cooked meals to fast food would see a sharp increase in GDP but, perhaps, a decrease in nutrition. Paid work need not be productive to be included in GDP. No adjustment is made for losses due to accidents, disasters, or depreciation of buildings and other capital.
Another factor not included in GDP is the price level in each country. Price levels vary from country to country and also from year to year. In Figure 2.1, not only is a comparison made between countries, but also between years. GDP numbers used for international or inter-year comparison are often, as here, adjusted for the â€œprice levelâ€ in each country in each year. The price level is determined by what it costs to buy a â€œmarket basketâ€ of goods. And that price level varies over the years, a process we call â€œinflation.â€
The GDP per capita presented in Figure 2.1 is adjusted for price level. The adjustment is often referred to as PPP, short for purchasing power parity. The units are 2011 â€œInternational Dollars,â€ a hypothetical currency for comparison between countries.











FigureÂ 2: Child mortality (deaths per 1000) versus GDP for 1960 and 2020. Source: Bolt and van Zanden â€“ Maddison Project Database 2023 â€“ with minor processing by [Our World in Data].
